$SPY if my only video game was a modern need for speed, I'd cry. 

These kids will never know a good need for speed game. 

These kids will probably not know a good call of duty ever again. Unless they remaster black ops 1 or mw2 Multiplayer. 

Honestly, I think $atvi would never make a mw2 remaster or bo1 remaster because that remaster would out sell the actual cod game for that year and just put them to shame. 

If they do a remaster it would definitely be after the $sne agreement ends and it's a Xbox exclusive. 

$ea better step their game up. $msft about to run this .

I'm still not buying an Xbox.

$SPY MAG was another shooter that was great but as a console exclusive to PS3, it didn't get enough attention. Plus it was in an era with mw2 bo1, bfbc2. It didn't have a chance. 

$sne $atvi $ea $msft

$SPY the greatest shooter of all time is tough to decide. 

Though I believe bo1 is the best call of duty, I believe mw2 is the goat because of how it bought a new generation of development to shooters. 

The jump between cod4, bfbc1, WaW, and then into mw2 is bigger than the generational jump between PS2 and PS3. 

I feel like the GOAT of shooters only has 2 choices: Mw2, or Bf3. I feel like Bf3 PC version is untouchable but nobody played that. Most Bf3 was on console and that version was limited on the console due to generational limitations. Perhaps the developers could've maxed out the PS3 with Bf3 but the xbox360 couldn't keep up. 

So consoles got stuck with crap. 

So by default, the Goat shooter is mw2.

$EA is currently scheduled to report quarterly results on May 10, while Take-Two ($TTWO) is slated to give its next quarterly report on May 16. 
 
In addition to Take-Two (TTWO) buying Zynga, the videogame market was shaken up earlier this year with Microsoft ($MSFT) saying it would acquire Activision Blizzard ($ATVI) for nearly $70 billion. On Thursday, Activision (ATVI) named two new female members to its company board of directors.

Microsoft's ($MSFT) deal with the U.S. Army for combat googles that was initially believed to be worth as much as $22 billion could be just half of that figure, Bloomberg reported. 
 
In a press conference, the Army, discussing a report from the Pentagon's inspector general, said the $21.9 billion Integrated Visual Augmentation System contract was an estimate that was a worst-case scenario and the most the service could cost. 
 
 
In June 2021, Microsoft (MSFT) said it signed a deal with the Army, which it said at the time could be worth $21.88 billion, to provide HoloLens technology for 120,000 headsets. 
 
At the time, the agreement was for five years, but it could be extended for another five years 
 
In October 2021, the Army confirmed that it was delaying the field testing of Microsoft's (MSFT) augmented-reality goggles until later in fiscal 2022. 
 
 
 
https://seekingalpha.com/news/3825884-microsoft-army-contract-for-combat-goggles-could-be-worth-half-of-22b-estimate-report
